description:
Caenorhabditis briggsae is a free-living, microscopic nematode (roundworm) species that belongs to the Caenorhabditis genus. It is a close relative of the well-studied model organism Caenorhabditis elegans, sharing many similarities in terms of genetic, developmental, and behavioral characteristics.

C. briggsae is a soil-dwelling organism, typically found in decaying organic matter, where it feeds on bacteria. Like C. elegans, it has a relatively simple body plan with a transparent cuticle, a simple nervous system, and a well-defined reproductive system. The species is capable of reproducing through both self-fertilization (hermaphroditism) and cross-fertilization (gonochorism).

Genetically, C. briggsae has a compact genome of approximately 100 million base pairs, containing around 20,000 protein-coding genes. The species exhibits considerable genetic diversity, with multiple naturally occurring strains that have been isolated from different geographical locations around the world.

C. briggsae has been extensively used as a comparative model organism alongside C. elegans to study various aspects of nematode biology, including developmental processes, gene regulation, aging, and host-pathogen interactions. The similarities and differences between these two closely related species have provided valuable insights into the evolution and conservation of biological mechanisms.
